Name: apple
Tips: Freezing guidance applies to cooked product
Environmental impact: nitrous oxide emission from fertilizer application; carbon dioxide from equipment use
Composting: Nitrogen helps compost break down, and apples are great sources of nitrogen.

Name: Apples

Environmental impact: nitrous oxide emission from fertilizer application; carbon dioxide from equipment use
Composting: Nitrogen helps compost break down, and apples are great sources of nitrogen.

Name: Asparagus
Purchasing: Look for firm, bright green and violet tinged asparagus that has compact tips
Tips: Stand up in a jar with water to keep it fresh longer
Environmental impact: greenhouse gases such as carbon dioxide
Composting: Can be added to compost materials

Name: avocado
Purchasing: Squeeze to see how ripe it is; choose harder avocados to eat later and softer avocados for immediate consumption
Tips: Ripe is when this item is tender, fully developed and ready to eat. To ripen, keep at room temperature in a paper bag until soft.
Environmental impact: need for deforestation and pesticide application, apart from mineral depletion from soil
Composting: As long as avocado stones and skin aren't composted, flesh can be quickly rotted down to provide nutrients to soil.

Name: Baby carrots
Purchasing: Make sure the carrots do not look dry and are bright in color
Environmental impact: pesticide use and long distance for transporting carrots
Composting: Cut them up into small chunks and fastest composting

Name: Bagged greens
Tips: Last 2 days if refigerated after opening
Environmental impact: uses a tremendous amount of water
Composting: Rich in nitrogen and protein

Name: banana
Purchasing: For perfectly ripe bananas, choose slightly firm and bright yellow bananas
Tips: Ripe is when this item is tender, fully developed and ready to eat.
Environmental impact: destruction of rainforests; pesticide application and soil fertility depletion
Composting: Add nutrients such as magnesium and sulfur to soil to promote healthy growth of plants.

Name: Blueberries
Purchasing: Avoid reddish blueberries, and always check the bottom of the packaging for bruised blueberries
Tips: Wash them in water and vinegar to keep them fresh longer
Composting: As long as compost around not too alkaline pH, or around 6.8 to 7.0, should be fine.

Name: broccoli
Purchasing: Look for broccoli with bright green heads.
Composting: Broccoli heads and leaves compost down pretty quickly. The stalk tends to take a lot longer � cut it into small chunks if you want it to rot down in a more timely fashion.

Name: Brussel sprouts
Purchasing: Check for bright green heads that are firmly packed and heavy for its size
Tips: Keep it in a plastic bag in the fridge and remove the yellow/wilted leaves for longer storage
Composting: Can be composted and, in fact, recommended for composting

Name: cauliflower
Tips: Cauliflower can be roasted, boiled, fried, steamed, or eaten raw
Composting: Break the head up into smaller chunks if you want it to rot down quickly; the leaves rot down quickly anyway.

Name: cheese
Tips: Cheese is a food derived from milk that is produced in a wide range of flavors, textures, and forms by coagulation of the milk protein casein.
Composting: It�s best not to compost cheese � or any other dairy products. While it will rot down, rats or other undesirable animals may be attracted to your compost heap in the meantime.
